I want to follow the integratd business resilience model suggestions - how can I integrate these two decks more seamlessly together and with the attached financial model spreadsheet followig the ideas here: [[[Integrated Business Resilience Framework: Efficiency, Risk & Values
Core Principles for Module Integration

Business-First Approach: Frame sustainability as a strategic business advantage with concrete benefits:

Risk reduction and operational resilience
Cost efficiency and resource optimization
Market differentiation and customer loyalty
Long-term business viability


Integration Method: Weave resilience concepts naturally into existing business modules by:

Enhancing existing examples with efficiency dimensions
Adding business case studies that demonstrate the alignment between values and profitability
Incorporating risk assessment into standard business planning frameworks
Updating facilitator notes with discussion prompts about long-term business durability


Practical Tools: Supplement modules with concrete decision-making tools:

Risk & Resilience Assessment worksheet to identify business vulnerabilities
Business Efficiency Checklist to locate cost-saving opportunities
"No-Regrets Path"  framework for customer journey mapping - meaning finding out customer values and be sure to meet their needs/wants while upholding their values 
Value-Aligned Menu Design for product/service offerings



Module-Specific Integration Points
UX/Customer Journey Mapping

Incorporate the "What's on the menu is what's on the mind" concept to show how businesses shape customer choices - ux shows a menu that constrain users so we need to be careful
Add the "No-Regrets Path" concept to prevent customer disappointment
Demonstrate how transparency about environmental attributes creates value for customers
Update examples to showcase customer satisfaction driven by values alignment

Business Model Canvas

Enhance the Value Proposition section to include differentiation through sustainability
Update Key Resources section to address resource efficiency and supply chain resilience
Expand Cost Structure section to identify efficiency opportunities
Add risk assessment to business assumptions testing

Cost Model

Incorporate resource efficiency into cost calculations
Demonstrate long-term ROI of efficiency investments
Add scenario planning for resource volatility and supply chain disruptions
Include operational efficiency metrics in financial projections

Implementation Framework

For Each Module:

Identify 3-4 high-impact slides for enhancement
Update facilitator notes with discussion prompts
Create a simple worksheet or tool if needed
Develop a business case example showing the business benefit


Cross-Module Integration:

Ensure concepts build progressively across modules
Reference previous learnings to reinforce connections
Maintain consistent terminology across all materials
Build toward comprehensive business resilience understanding


Measurement Approach:

Develop metrics that focus on business outcomes
Include both short-term efficiency gains and long-term resilience indicators
Connect environmental improvements to financial performance
Enable businesses to track progress with simple tools



This framework provides a comprehensive approach to integrating sustainability as a core business strategy focused on efficiency, risk management, and values alignment ‚Äì all driving toward long-term business success and resilience.]]]

To seamlessly integrate the **Cost Model**, **Balance Sheet**, and **Financial Model Spreadsheet** using the **Integrated Business Resilience Framework**, here‚Äôs how we can approach it: ### **1. Integration Strategy** The **Cost Model (Session 9)** and **Balance Sheet (Session 10)** both contribute to the **Financial Model**, but currently, they exist as separate instructional materials. To align with the resilience framework, we need to: - Frame **efficiency** and **risk reduction** as strategic business advantages. - Use **customer journey mapping** and **value-aligned decision-making** to enhance financial decision-making. - Incorporate **long-term resilience** metrics into financial planning. --- ### **2. Key Enhancements** | **Module** | **Integration with Resilience Framework** | |--------------------|------------------------------------------| | **Cost Model** | - Introduce **resource efficiency calculations** in cost structures.
- Emphasize **long-term cost savings** from investments (e.g., bulk orders, durable equipment).
- Include **risk assessment for price fluctuations** (e.g., energy costs, material shortages).
- Add a **worksheet** on **"No-Regrets Path"** for cost management (aligning costs with customer values). | | **Balance Sheet** | - Include a **Resilience Metrics Section** (tracking sustainability-driven efficiencies).
- Link **CAPEX vs. OPEX decisions** to long-term financial health.
- Demonstrate how **investment in efficiency** impacts balance sheet stability.
- Add case examples of businesses leveraging **sustainability as a competitive advantage**. | | **Financial Model** | - Add a **scenario planning section** to test resilience against resource volatility.
- Incorporate **business efficiency checklists** into cost and revenue projections.
- Connect **risk & resilience assessments** to cash flow management.
- Ensure financial ratios highlight **both short-term gains and long-term stability**. | --- ### **3. Specific Action Plan** #### **Cost Model Adjustments** - **Integrate Resilience Thinking into COGS Calculation:** - Introduce **bulk purchase scenarios** to compare long-term cost efficiency. - Add a **sustainability cost-benefit analysis** (e.g., comparing cheap vs. durable materials). - Show examples of **cost risk mitigation strategies** (e.g., supplier diversification, hedging strategies). - **Enhance Decision-Making with a Risk & Resilience Assessment Tool** - A simple worksheet for startups to evaluate **operational efficiency risks**. - Example: "If energy prices rise by 10%, how does this impact production costs?" - This ties into scenario planning in the Financial Model. #### **Balance Sheet Adjustments** - **Incorporate Efficiency and Risk Management Metrics** - Introduce **long-term investment ROI tracking** (CAPEX vs. operational costs). - Highlight how **resource-efficient strategies** affect liabilities and equity. - **Connect Balance Sheet to the "No-Regrets Path"** - Ensure customer-driven business values align with **financial decision-making**. - Example: If customers value sustainability, should assets reflect eco-friendly investments? #### **Financial Model Adjustments** - **Introduce Scenario Planning in Cash Flow Management** - Build a resilience-driven scenario modeling tool. - Example: "How does a 5% increase in energy costs affect financial health?" - **Align Financial Ratios with Business Resilience** - Add a metric to show how **efficiency investments impact financial sustainability**. - Example: "How do upfront efficiency costs lower long-term operational expenses?" --- ### **4. Implementation Framework** To apply this within the training modules: - **Identify 3-4 High-Impact Slides for Each Module** - Cost Model: Slides on **COGS, Efficiency, Bulk Purchases**. - Balance Sheet: Slides on **Assets, Liabilities, CAPEX/OPEX**. - Financial Model: Slides on **Cash Flow, Scenario Planning**. - **Update Facilitator Notes** - Add discussion prompts like: *"How does reducing operational waste improve financial sustainability?"* - **Create a Business Case Example** - Example: A business that **switched to energy-efficient operations** and **increased long-term profitability**. --- ### **Next Steps** - Do you want me to **edit the decks** directly with these integrations? - Or should we create **supplementary worksheets and facilitator notes** to enhance the current content? This will ensure that the **Cost Model, Balance Sheet, and Financial Model** work **seamlessly within the Integrated Business Resilience Framework** while maintaining clarity for the entrepreneurs using them. Let me know how you'd like to proceed!

### **Revised Analysis: Integrating the Cost Model, Balance Sheet, and Financial Model using the Integrated Business Resilience Framework**

#### **Key Observations from Review**
1. **Sustainability as a Business Strategy**: The decks treat sustainability separately rather than as an inherent part of cost modeling and financial planning.
2. **Risk & Resilience Integration Gap**: The **Balance Sheet deck** doesn‚Äôt explicitly connect financial structure to business resilience.
3. **Efficiency‚Äôs Impact on Costs and Long-Term Financial Health**: The **Cost Model deck** discusses efficiency but doesn‚Äôt fully explore **how resource efficiency impacts long-term costs**.
4. **Lack of Value-Based Decision-Making Framework**: Neither deck strongly connects **customer values and environmental choices** with financial performance.

---
### **Before & After Changes ‚Äì Step by Step Implementation**

#### **1. Reframe Resource Efficiency as a Core Cost Factor**
**Before**: Resource efficiency is treated as a separate topic in the Cost Model (appears late, not deeply connected to financial decisions).
- **Issue**: It feels like an "extra" rather than a strategic cost-reduction and resilience-building tool.

**After**: Move **resource efficiency** considerations **earlier** in the Cost Model deck (around Slide 5).  
- Introduce a **Resource Efficiency ROI Table** showing **payback periods** and **long-term cost savings**.
- Explicitly **link efficiency investments** to **financial statements** (showing their impact on the Balance Sheet).

üîπ **Example Change for Cost Model Slide 5**:
---
**Strategic Efficiency Investments ‚Äì Impact on Business Costs**
| **Investment** | **Initial Cost** | **Annual Savings** | **Payback Period** | **Balance Sheet Impact** |
|--------------|---------------|---------------|---------------|----------------------|
| Solar Panels | $3,000 | $1,200 | 2.5 years | Fixed Asset ‚Äì Reduces Monthly OpEx |
| LED Lighting | $500 | $250 | 2 years | Fixed Asset ‚Äì Energy Cost Savings |
| Local Sourcing | $800 | $300 | 2.7 years | COGS Reduction ‚Äì Supply Chain Stability |
---
- This connects **cost reduction** to **financial resilience** (appearing in **cost structure, efficiency, and balance sheet entries**).

---

#### **2. Incorporate Risk Assessment in Cost Planning**
**Before**: The Cost Model deck doesn‚Äôt highlight how **different costs impact business resilience**.
- No discussion of **supply chain risks, operational disruptions, or financial risks** in cost structure.

**After**: Add a **Risk & Resilience Column** in cost breakdowns.
- Show **how supplier diversification, energy independence, and efficiency choices reduce business risk**.

üîπ **Example Change for Cost Model Slide 15**
---
**SG&A EXPENSES ‚Äì Risk & Resilience Considerations**
| **Expense Item** | **Monthly Cost** | **Risk Reduction Value** |
|----------------|--------------|------------------|
| Local Suppliers | $XXX | Reduces supply chain disruption risk by XX% |
| Renewable Energy | $XXX | Eliminates price volatility risk of $XXX/year |
| Process Automation | $XXX | Reduces operational downtime by XX% |
---
- This **connects efficiency decisions to financial stability** and ensures entrepreneurs **think beyond costs to resilience**.

---

#### **3. Align Business Efficiency Workbook with Financial Model**
**Before**: The **Business Efficiency Workbook** operates separately from the financial model.
- The **prioritization of efficiency actions** does not directly influence financial forecasts.

**After**: **Create a direct mapping** between efficiency improvements in the workbook and **financial projections**.
- Add **a slide to show how workbook priorities feed into the financial model**.

üîπ **Example New Slide for Cost Model (Efficiency Workbook Integration)**
---
**Business Efficiency Workbook ‚Üí Financial Model Integration**
| **Priority Action** | **Efficiency Score** | **Financial Impact** |
|------------------|----------------|----------------|
| Process Optimization | 5.0 | -$100/month in operating costs |
| Solar Panel Investment | 4.8 | -$22/month energy costs, +$3,000 fixed asset |
| Local Sourcing | 2.2 | Supplier risk ‚Üì 30% |
---
- **This ensures decisions made in the efficiency workbook directly impact financial modeling**.

---

#### **4. Strengthen Balance Sheet‚Äôs Role in Resilience**
**Before**: The **Balance Sheet deck** teaches financial structure but **doesn‚Äôt connect assets and liabilities to business resilience**.

**After**: Add a **Resilience Indicators Section** to track **how financial health supports business sustainability**.
- Introduce **new resilience-focused financial ratios**.

üîπ **Example Addition to Balance Sheet Slide 17**
---
**Resilience Indicators from Your Balance Sheet**
| **Metric** | **Current** | **Target** | **Why It Matters** |
|-------------|----------|---------|-----------------|
| Cash Ratio | XX% | >30% | Ensures liquidity in crisis |
| Resource Efficiency Assets | $XXX | XX% of total assets | Long-term cost reduction |
| Diversification Score | XX/100 | >80 | Lowers risk exposure |
---
- This **helps entrepreneurs see financial planning as a tool for long-term business stability**.

---

#### **5. Introduce "No-Regrets Path" for Financial Decision-Making**
**Before**: Financial decisions in the decks focus on **profitability but not resilience**.
- No framework to show **how certain investments provide benefits across multiple business scenarios**.

**After**: **Create a "No-Regrets" Decision Framework**.
- Highlight **decisions that are beneficial regardless of market conditions**.

üîπ **Example New Slide for Financial Decision-Making**
---
**No-Regrets Financial Decisions**
| **Investment** | **Positive ROI** | **Customer Value** | **Risk Reduction** |
|----------------|---------------|---------------|---------------|
| Solar Panels | ‚úì | ‚úì | ‚úì |
| LED Lighting | ‚úì | - | ‚úì |
| Local Suppliers | ‚úì | ‚úì | ‚úì |
---
- This **helps entrepreneurs make strategic choices that align with financial stability, customer trust, and operational resilience**.

---

### **Summary of Key Changes**
| **Before** | **After** |
|----------|---------|
| Sustainability appears as a separate section | Integrated into cost planning, balance sheet, and financial model |
| No risk assessment in cost model | Risk assessment added to SG&A and cost planning |
| Business Efficiency Workbook disconnected from financials | Direct link between efficiency workbook and financial model |
| Balance sheet teaches mechanics but lacks resilience focus | New **Resilience Indicators** added |
| Financial decisions focused only on profitability | New **No-Regrets Decision Framework** added |

---
### **Step-by-Step Implementation for Deck Updates**
‚úÖ **For Cost Model Deck**:
1. **Slide 5**: Add **Resource Efficiency ROI** Table.
2. **Slide 6**: Connect **COGS with Efficiency Choices**.
3. **Slide 15**: **Risk & Resilience** column in cost planning.
4. **New Slide**: Business Efficiency Workbook Integration.

‚úÖ **For Balance Sheet Deck**:
1. **Slide 17**: Add **Resilience Metrics**.
2. **Slide 18**: Show how **resource efficiency investments** appear as assets.
3. **New Slide**: **Resilience Effect** of financial decisions.

‚úÖ **For Financial Model**:
1. **Create a new tab** for **Resource Efficiency Analysis**.
2. **Add comparative projections**: Efficiency vs. Traditional approach.
3. **Risk scoring** for different financial strategies.

---
### **Final Thoughts**
By implementing these changes:
- Entrepreneurs **see sustainability as a business advantage**, not an extra cost.
- The **Balance Sheet becomes a tool for long-term resilience**, not just a financial snapshot.
- **Financial decisions align with business efficiency and risk reduction**.

Would you like me to **edit the decks** directly with these changes? Or should we **draft facilitator notes and worksheets** to guide implementation?

**Analyzing and comparing**

I‚Äôm assessing the current content, cross-referencing it with the new analysis, and then redoing the analysis. The aim is to pinpoint clear improvement areas with detailed "before/after changes" for comprehension.

**Initiating a comprehensive review**

Starting with the latest analysis, I'll revisit resource efficiency, risk assessment, financial planning integration, balance sheet alignment, and outlining a "no regrets path." A detailed comparison will follow.

**Integrating changes**

I‚Äôm adding columns for risk reduction and resilience, revising cost model and balance sheet slides, and crafting a comprehensive table to illustrate "before/after" scenarios.

Below is a **fresh, step-by-step analysis** that compares the original Cost Model and Balance Sheet decks with the updated recommendations. I've highlighted **‚ÄúBefore‚Äù** (the current state) vs. **‚ÄúAfter‚Äù** (the improved version), followed by **how** to implement each change and **why** it matters. This gives you a clear roadmap to integrate these decks more seamlessly with the Financial Model spreadsheet, all while aligning with the **Integrated Business Resilience Framework**. --- ## 1. Reframe Resource Efficiency as a Strategic Business Advantage ### **BEFORE** - **Cost Model Deck**: Resource efficiency might appear as a separate bullet or slide (e.g., ‚Äúoptional sustainability considerations‚Äù), without clear ROI examples. - **Balance Sheet Deck**: Investments in efficiency (like solar panels, better insulation, etc.) are not explicitly shown under assets or future cost savings. - **Financial Model**: No direct linkage (e.g., a user can‚Äôt easily see how an efficiency measure impacts monthly costs or overall ROI). ### **AFTER** 1. **Cost Model Deck** - Move **resource efficiency** content into the **core** COGS/SG&A slides. - Include **concrete ROI** calculations for efficiency measures (e.g., LED lighting, water-saving devices). - Show **payback period** and **long-term cost savings** in the same slide where you list normal expenses. 2. **Balance Sheet Deck** - Add a line item under **‚ÄúFixed Assets‚Äù** or **‚ÄúProperty, Plant & Equipment‚Äù** for resource-efficiency investments (e.g., ‚ÄúSolar Panels - $3,000‚Äù). - Use **notes** or a small table to highlight the **expected 3-year ROI** or depreciation schedule. 3. **Financial Model** - Create a simple **toggle or line item** (e.g., ‚ÄúEnergy-Saving Equipment‚Äù cost) under CAPEX. - Show the resulting **monthly cost reduction** in Operating Expenses (e.g., a formula that subtracts $X from the monthly electricity expense once the asset is added). ### **HOW to implement & WHY** - **How**: 1. In the **Cost Model slide** where you summarize costs, add a **column** for ‚ÄúEfficiency Investment‚Äù with sub-columns for ‚ÄúInitial Cost,‚Äù ‚ÄúOngoing Savings,‚Äù and ‚ÄúPayback Period.‚Äù 2. what are the equations for payback period and 3 year ROI

Here are the **equations** for **Payback Period** and **3-Year ROI**:

---

### **üìå Payback Period (in Months)**  
The payback period tells us how long it takes to recover the initial investment through savings.

\[
\text{Payback Period (Months)} = \frac{\text{Initial Investment Cost}}{\text{Monthly Savings}}
\]

**Example:**  
If a **solar panel** costs **$3,000** and saves **$125 per month**, then:

\[
\text{Payback Period} = \frac{3,000}{125} = 24 \text{ months}
\]

---

### **üìå 3-Year ROI (%)**  
The **Return on Investment (ROI)** over three years is calculated as:

\[
\text{3-Year ROI} = \left( \frac{\text{Total Savings Over 3 Years} - \text{Initial Cost}}{\text{Initial Cost}} \right) \times 100
\]

Since **Total Savings Over 3 Years** is:

\[
\text{Total Savings Over 3 Years} = \text{Monthly Savings} \times 36
\]

The final formula becomes:

\[
\text{3-Year ROI} = \left( \frac{(\text{Monthly Savings} \times 36) - \text{Initial Cost}}{\text{Initial Cost}} \right) \times 100
\]

**Example:**  
For a **solar panel** that costs **$3,000** and saves **$125 per month**:

1. **Total Savings Over 3 Years**  
   \[
   125 \times 36 = 4,500
   \]

2. **ROI Calculation**  
   \[
   \left( \frac{4,500 - 3,000}{3,000} \right) \times 100 = \left( \frac{1,500}{3,000} \right) \times 100 = 50\%
   \]

---

### **üéØ Summary of Formulas**
| **Metric**        | **Formula** |
|------------------|------------|
| **Payback Period (Months)** | \( \frac{\text{Initial Investment Cost}}{\text{Monthly Savings}} \) |
| **3-Year ROI (%)** | \( \left( \frac{(\text{Monthly Savings} \times 36) - \text{Initial Cost}}{\text{Initial Cost}} \right) \times 100 \) |

The first thing we will go over are the Cost of Goods Sold (COGS). Again COGS are the direct costs of producing an item sold by a company. This includes the cost of the materials and labor directly used to create the product itself. 
So for example, if you sell T-shirts, you need to calculate the cost of actually producing that item. Whether you are buying it from someone else, or producing it from scratch, these costs have to be accounted for.

---

### **Facilitator Notes for "Resource Efficiency ROI Calculator" Slide**  

#### **Objective of this Slide:**  
This slide helps participants understand how **strategic efficiency investments** impact financial performance. It introduces the concept of **payback periods, ROI, and risk reduction** for capital investments in resource-efficient systems.

#### **Key Points to Cover:**  
1. **Strategic Investments:**  
   - Some business expenses are not just costs but **investments** that **save money over time** (e.g., solar panels, LED lighting, water-saving systems).  
   - These investments improve **efficiency, lower operating costs, and enhance sustainability**.

2. **Understanding the Metrics:**  
   - **Initial Cost:** The upfront investment required to implement the improvement.  
   - **Annual Savings:** The amount of money saved per year due to the investment.  
   - **Payback Period:** The time it takes for the savings to **cover the initial cost** (calculated as Initial Cost √∑ Annual Savings).  
   - **3-Year ROI:** The return on investment over three years, expressed as a percentage:  
     \[
     \left( \frac{(\text{Annual Savings} \times 3) - \text{Initial Cost}}{\text{Initial Cost}} \right) \times 100
     \]  
   - **Risk Reduction:** Investments in efficiency **reduce financial risks** (e.g., energy price fluctuations, resource scarcity, maintenance costs).

3. **How it Appears in Financial Statements:**  
   - **Balance Sheet:** These investments are listed under **Fixed Assets**.  
   - **Profit & Loss (P&L) Statement:** They reduce **monthly expenses** by lowering utility or operational costs.  
   - **Customer Perception:** Many efficiency upgrades improve a company's **brand reputation and customer trust** (e.g., sustainability efforts).

#### **Facilitation Approach:**  
- **Ask:** How many of you have considered making strategic efficiency investments in your business?  
- **Discussion:**  
  - Which efficiency improvements could benefit your business?  
  - Would you prioritize **short-term payback** or **long-term savings**?  
- **Practical Application:**  
  - Encourage entrepreneurs to **identify one investment** that could lower their costs long-term and integrate it into their financial model.  

---

### **Do We Need This Slide?**  
This slide is **valuable if** the goal is to **encourage entrepreneurs to think about smart long-term investments**. However, if it feels redundant or off-track from the core cost model session, consider **integrating efficiency investments into SG&A or Capex discussions** rather than having a separate slide.
it doesn't seem like it fits into the cost model, it's all about COGS, we talk about capex in the next session, shouldn't it go there?

Yes, it makes more sense to **move this slide to the Capex session** instead of keeping it in the cost model session.  

### **Reasons to Move the Slide to Capex:**
1. **Cost Model Focuses on Operational Costs:**  
   - The cost model session is centered on **COGS, salaries, and SG&A**‚Äîexpenses that occur regularly as part of running the business.  
   - Strategic efficiency investments (like solar panels or water systems) are **capital expenditures (Capex),** which are usually one-time investments with long-term benefits.

2. **Capex Session Covers Asset Investments & Depreciation:**  
   - Capital expenditures (like energy-efficient lighting, machinery, or sustainability upgrades) **appear on the balance sheet** rather than being immediate operating expenses.  
   - The **ROI and payback period** calculations fit better in a discussion on **financial planning for long-term investments** rather than the day-to-day cost model.

3. **Streamlining the Cost Model Session:**  
   - Keeping the cost model focused on **short-term and recurring expenses** makes it more digestible for entrepreneurs.  
   - Entrepreneurs will have a clearer understanding of **what costs they can optimize today** (COGS, salaries, SG&A) vs. **what investments they should plan for later** (Capex).

### **Next Steps:**

### **Facilitator Notes: Strategic Efficiency Investments (Now in Capex Session)**  

#### **Objective:**  
Explain how **capital investments** in efficiency (e.g., energy-saving systems, water conservation, durable equipment) can **reduce long-term costs** and improve **financial sustainability.**  

#### **Key Points to Cover:**
- **What are Strategic Efficiency Investments?**  
  - These are **one-time purchases** that reduce **ongoing operating expenses** over time.  
  - Examples:  
    - **Solar panels ‚Üí reduce electricity costs**  
    - **LED lighting ‚Üí lower energy bills + fewer replacements**  
    - **Water systems ‚Üí cut down on water consumption and waste**  
  - These appear on the **balance sheet as fixed assets** rather than day-to-day expenses.

- **Why Do They Matter?**  
  - While these require upfront spending, they **pay for themselves over time** through **cost savings** and potentially **increased brand value.**  
  - They **reduce financial risk** by making costs more predictable (e.g., protection from rising energy prices).  
  - Some investments can also **improve customer perception** (e.g., sustainable businesses attract more eco-conscious customers).

- **How to Evaluate an Investment?**  
  - **Payback Period = Initial Cost / Annual Savings**  
    - Example: If LED lighting costs **$500** and saves **$240 per year**, the **payback period is ~2.1 years.**  
  - **3-Year ROI (%) = (Total Savings Over 3 Years / Initial Cost) √ó 100**  
    - Example: If solar panels cost **$3,000** and save **$960 per year**, the **3-year ROI is 96%**.  

- **Decision-Making:**  
  - Not all efficiency investments make sense for every business‚Äîconsider:  
    - **Can you afford the upfront cost?**  
    - **How quickly will you break even?**  
    - **What is the long-term benefit beyond just cost savings?**

Resource Efficiency & CAP-EX, OP-EX
Resource efficiency investments can be either CAPEX or OPEX:
CAPEX: Long-term assets that provide efficiency over time.
Example: Solar panels (25+ years), energy-efficient equipment (5‚Äì10 years), water recycling systems (10+ years).
OPEX: Short-term operational expenses that improve efficiency.
Example: LED bulbs (if inexpensive), energy audits, staff training on conservation
Example:
A $3,000 solar panel investment is a CAPEX item that depreciates over 25 years, while an LED retrofit at $200 might be an OPEX cost.

The method of spreading the cost of an asset over the course of its useful life.
AMORTIZATION AND DEPRECIATION
Why do this?
Smaller impact on P&L
More accurate #‚Äôs
5-10 minutes: Lecture + demonstration

Now that we have a clear picture of our startup costs, and we have determined if we will expense or capitalize on them, we can move into the next part, Amortization & depreciation. Do remember seeing this on your P&L? We said we would get to it later. Now we are here!

Amortization and depreciation are ways to spread the cost of an asset over the course of its useful life. 
By doing this, you will have a smaller impact on your P&L. When you buy very expensive assets that aren‚Äôt typical in your yearly expenses, you don‚Äôt want them to reflect on your P&L. This will give people the wrong idea of what you are spending month to month to operate your business. If it shows up as an expense on your profit and loss, that will look bad for investors or other people interested in your company. You want to minimize the expenses on the P&L to look more profitable.
Stay as accurate as possible to understand month to month or year to year changes. If you have random large expenses in your P&L, you wont get an accurate picture of your normal spending habits. 

Amortization is a method of spreading the cost of an intangible asset over a specific period of time, which is usually the course of its useful life. Intangible assets are non-physical assets that are nonetheless essential to a company, such as patents, trademarks, and copyrights. The goal in amortizing an asset is to match the expense of acquiring it with the revenue it generates.
Example: Let's say a company spends $50,000 to obtain a license, and the license in question will expire in 10 years. Since the license is an intangible asset, it should be amortized for the 10-year period leading up to its expiration date. Using the straight-line method of amortization, which is a method for charging a cost to an expense at a consistent rate over time, the company's annual amortization expense for the license will be $5,000 (that's $50,000/10 years), meaning the asset will decline in value by $5,000 every year.
Depreciation: Like amortization, depreciation is a method of spreading the cost of an asset over a specified period of time, typically the asset's useful life. The purpose of depreciation is to match the expense of obtaining an asset to the income it helps a company earn. Depreciation is used for tangible assets, which are physical assets such as manufacturing equipment, business vehicles, and computers. Depreciation is a measure of how much of an asset's value has been used up at a given point in time.
Example: Let's say a company purchases a new piece of equipment with an estimated useful life of 10 years for¬†the price of $100,000. Using the straight-line method, the company's annual depreciation expense for the equipment will be $10,000 ($100,000/10 years). This is important because depreciation expenses are recognized as deductions for tax purposes. It is also possible for a company to use an accelerated depreciation method, where the amount of depreciation it takes each year is higher during the earlier years of an asset's life.

For the purpose of simplicity, we are going to put everything under depreciation for now, but you can separate them on your financials if you would like to be more detailed.

So how do we calculate the depreciation? That is easy! 
We just add 1 more column of information which is ‚Äúestimated useful lifetime value (in years)
So for each of your capitalized expenses, think about how long it will last. Write the number of years in the yellow space. 
Some of these things have international standards (for example, a computer is said to have a useful life of 5 years even though it will still work after that time), but you can always estimate if you don‚Äôt know. 
Then you take the value of the item and divide it by the number of years to find its yearly value.
Do an example on the board!
Ask: You bought a new computer that you bought for $500. What is the monthly and yearly depreciation value?
Step 1: determine lifetime value: 5 years
Step 2: Divide value by the number of useful years: $500/5=$100/year
Step 3: Divide yearly value by 12 months: $100/12=$8.333
Ask: What does this mean?
Every year, your computer will lose about $100 in value or $8.33 per year.
This is shown as an expense on your P&L as $8.33 month to month instead of $500 all at once!
You will do this for all of your capitalized assets to show a total yearly and monthly depreciation value (show animation).

A balance sheet is one of the three major business statements.
It shows what the business owns, what it owes, and the value of the owner's investment in the business.

Your balance sheet shows your financial health in a single point of time. You don‚Äôt evaluate it over time like a P&L. Instead, you look at your assets and liabilities in a single point in time to understand your net worth. 
Many financial ratios use information in your balance sheet. With these ratios you can get a better idea of your financial health.

PREPARE YOUR BALANCE SHEET
2 minutes: Lecture

In theory it is a very simple document summed up by a simple formula. The difficult part is creating an accurate representation of each of these categories. 
As we said before, the balance sheet shows what you have vs what you owe.

ASSETS
More information about the balance sheet with examples. They don‚Äôt record all of this on their balance sheet so it can be confusing for entrepreneurs. But it is good to understand all the other parts of a balance sheet for future recording. 

5 minutes: Lecture

Assets are the things that you have. They can be long term or current (short term) assets. These assets contribute to the success of your business and are (hopefully) contributing to your long term growth!
Current assets: This includes cash and things that can easily turn into cash. Things such as inventory can be easily turned into cash by selling the item. These things usually can be converted to cash within the year.
Cash: Cash in the bank is an asset!
Accounts receivable: The amount of money that people owe you. Maybe you already delivered a product/service but haven‚Äôt received payment yet. This should be reported!
Inventory: Do you have a lot of items that are ready to be sold? You can include their value here.
Prepaid rent: Did you already pay for something and the value of that item is still owed to you? You can also include this. This is the same as prepaid salaries or other non-monetary things owed to you. 
Long term assets: These are assets that have value, but they aren‚Äôt very liquid (can‚Äôt turn into cash easily). This includes things like machinery, property, technology, and other big investments.
Land: Property is valuable and should be recorded as something that adds value in your business.
Buildings & improvements: Not only can you count the physical building, but you can count how much you spent to improve the building. Maybe you build a handicap ramp, or installed walls, even painting the walls count here. They are all investments into your business that will last a long time and increase the value of your assets.
Furniture & fixtures: These are things that you have invested into your business and should be accounted for.
General equipment: Machinery and other equipment are valuable parts of your business that help you generate revenues and operate!

LIABILITIES + OWNERS EQUITY
More information about the balance sheet with examples. They don‚Äôt record all of this on their balance sheet so it can be confusing for entrepreneurs. But it is good to understand all the other parts of a balance sheet for future recording. 

5 minutes: Lecture

Now that we have shown exactly what we have, we need to show how we paid for it. You are either paying for your business with money you (and investors) put in in exchange for owners equity, or you take out a loan (debt). Between these two things, it shows exactly how you paid for all of your assets.

What you owe:
Current liabilities: These are things that you owe people within the year. If you borrow money from someone and you need to pay it back. Or if you buy something from a business and haven‚Äôt paid for it yet (and you owe them the money within the year). 
Accounts payable: This is the opposite of accounts receivable (shown as an asset). If you have received a product or service, but you still owe cash, you would need to show that.  Any time that you owe cash to or services to people, you would put it as a current liability. 
Long term liabilities: This is what you owe that you don‚Äôt have to pay back for at least a year. If you take out a loan, it will usually be under here.
Owners equity: This covers your personal contribution to your business and also investment. It is the owners (including partners) money that they have invested. Additionally, all of the money that your business has generated through sales that you have retained from the previous years would be reported here as well (this will keep your growing cash balanced- How are you getting the increased amount of cash on your assets? Through the retained earnings under owner‚Äôs equity- you don‚Äôt owe this to anyone except shareholders of your business, including yourself).

5 minutes: Lecture + demonstration

Instead, we will look here instead to explain how we are tracking owners equity and linking it to your assets.
Capital: This is all the money in your business right now. It equals your total startup costs + you personal contribution (this is coming from what you ask for on the startup costs)
Retained earnings: The retained earnings is the money that you keep in your business from the previous year. You can see how it accumulates over the year in your net income and then it shows in the second year. It is equal to the previous years net income. 
Net income: This is your bottom line reported month to month on your profit and loss tab. 
Total equity: Your total equity is the sum of your capital, retained earnings, and net income. You pay for your assets (and cash) through the money you make through your business activities!

When you add your total equity and total liabilities (from loans and money you owe other people/businesses) it should equal your total assets.

BALANCE SHEET AFTER A LOAN
20 minutes: Discussion + demonstration

5 minutes: Discussion
Now let‚Äôs assume that you win money, get investment, or take out a loan. You will want to show how that cash injection will change your financials. With new cash, your business can now pay for more things. You will want to show what you are buying, and also where that money came from. Let‚Äôs look at an example together:

Ask: Can anyone tell me what happened here (in the picture above)?
Answers: 
This business took out a loan for $50,000. This is shown as a long term loan/liability because it will take over a year to pay it back (if you have to pay it back in less than a year it will be a current liability). 
Total liabilities and owner‚Äôs equity raised to $63,500 because it is the total of the new loan + the original loan of $1000 + the $12,500 that you put in at the beginning (you might need to go back to the previous slide to show exactly how the right side of the balance sheet has changed).
Now you have to do something with that new money which is shown. If you don‚Äôt do anything with the money, it will show up in your assets as cash. This means you have money you can use, but you haven‚Äôt spent anything.
But according to this balance sheet, the business did spend money. They spent $40,000 on inventory and $10,000 on more furniture and fixtures. 
No matter how you spend that money, your assets will always equal the total liabilities and owner‚Äôs equity (because it will be cash or something else). 

Recap: What changed?
Loans and long term liabilities increased by 50k. It went here because it is a loan you will have to pay back. Not equity. It is also long term because it isn‚Äôt meant to be paid back in less than a year. That 50k is a long term liability.
Where are you spending this money? You paid for inventory and furniture.
Someone looking at this would be interested to see how you spend your money. Is it sitting as cash? 50k as cash doesn‚Äôt grow for you. People want to see smart investments with the money. 

Another example:
Ask: You just saw an example of a loan, but what would it look like if you got investment? How would your balance sheet change?
Answers:
The amount of investment will be shown in owners equity. It is not a loan and it is not expected to be paid back.
